content.content: When a patient is taking narcotic pain medication with a computerized pump called a PCA (Patient Controlled Analgesia), they need: - Continuous pulse oximetry with centralized alarms ![Pulse Oximeter](//images.ctfassets.net/xbvvg00rroa3/62HmzU3IeA4QugCgOKEKKw/267477dfe9966f5d1053a8ae68e08060/Pulse_Oximeter.jpg) - Continuous ventilation monitoring (capnography) ![Respiratory Monitoring](//images.ctfassets.net/xbvvg00rroa3/6BT07hj6KWkq02U8e8sW2a/6b55b09879e2cb39bd9c57a0c4beaf2c/Respiratory_Monitoring.jpg) - Assessment by family and friends[^7][^32][^33][^34][^35][^36] - Pulse oximetry indirectly measures a patient's oxygen level (SpO2) in the blood. - Capnography non-invasively measures a patient's carbon dioxide (ventilation) level when they breath out.[^34] - The normal range for capnography (ETCO2) is between 35-40 mmHg.[^35] - Capnography gives an early warning of respiratory depression (dangerously slow breathing) compared with pulse oximetry.[^32][^33][^34][^35][^36] Normal adult breathing rate is 12 to 16 breaths per minute. You can count how many times the patient's chest rises over 1 minute.[^16][^17] __Pediatric Respiratory Rates__ | Age | Breaths per Minute | |-------------------------|--------------------| | Infant (Birth to 1 yr.) | 30 to 60 | | Toddler (1-3 yrs.) | 24 to 40 | | Preschooler (3-6 yrs.) | 22 to 34 | | School age (6-12 yrs.) | 18 to 30 | | Adolescent (12-18 yrs.) | 12 to 16 | Embedded content: https://youtu.be/jHZuuEAmDSE Embedded content: https://youtu.be/fqMCt6o24Ss ## Prevention __Use the Hospital Plan of Care form to advocate and ask questions about your loved one.__ [The Hospital Plan of Care form](https://patientsafetymovement.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/POC-Blank-April-19.pdf "The Hospital Plan of Care form") [Guide to Medical Care at a Distance](https://patientsafetymovement.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Guide-to-Medical-Care-at-a-Distance.pdf "Guide to Medical Care at a Distance") 1\. Bring the patient's CPAP to the hospital if used at home. Obstructive Sleep Apnea (OSA) patients have a much higher risk for respiratory depression (dangerously slow breathing).[^7] 2\. Constipation is common side effect from opioid (narcotic) medications-the patient should get bowel medications to prevent this.[^7] [Hospital Medication Safety Information by the National Library of Medicine ](https://medlineplus.gov/ency/patientinstructions/000501.htm) 3\. Make sure your nurse scans your wristband to verify your name before giving you any medication if the hospital has this system.[^7] Embedded content: https://youtu.be/rbVO5Qc_wJ8 4\. Report all drug reactions to your nurse at the hospital. Tell your nurse to report any drug error. Ask for the nursing supervisor or attending doctor about this adverse drug report.[^7] You or your advocate can report a drug error to: Institute for Safe Medication Practices Medication Errors Reporting Program (MERP): 1-215-947-77977 or: [Institute for Safe Medication Practices](https://merp.consumermedsafety.org/merp.aspx "Institute for Safe Medication Practices") Embedded content: https://youtu.be/wIbfwlV1XH4 Embedded content: https://youtu.be/9cQ-K5MDtQc [Hospital Medication Safety Information by the National Library of Medicine](https://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/ency/patientinstructions/000501.htm "Hospital medication safety information by the National Library of Medicine") [Opioid Fact Sheet from the Empowered Patient Coalition](http://patientsafetymovement.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/ten-things-opioid-fact-sheet.pdf) [Opioid Pain Medication Information from ISMP Canada](https://www.ismp-canada.org/download/OpioidStewardship/opioid-handout-bw.pdf) [^7]: Hallisey J.
